title: Can the protagonist and antagonist be the same person? - Quora

response.answer_text: I don’t think so. An antagonist is the one that’s the story counterpart of the protagonist, so they can’t be the same person. Villain What can be done is that the protagonist is the villain, the bad guy. Some stories will actually tell you from the very beginning that the protagonist is a bad guy. Heists are often those kind of stories, as the protagonist actually robs people. That technically makes him a bad guy, no matter how much you justify his actions - although he will be more sympathetic if the heist is done at a company that robs other people. Dexter, the serial killer from the TV series might classify as a villain, but I’d rather brand him an anti-hero. After all, he only kills bad guys when he feels he has to kill someone. He can’t help killing people, so he goes after the people who deserve it - in his eyes at least, as he does have a sense of justice. In that sense he’s no different from The Punisher or even Venom. There have also been stories where at the end it’s revealed that the protagonist you’ve been following throughout the story turned out to be the villain. Exception The only exception I can think of is when you’re writing a story about a protagonist with a Multiple Personality Disorder. That way your protagonist and antagonist occupy the same body, although they’re different people. I hope that answered your question.

Yes, but it is a matter of viewer perspective. Some recent examples of this are “The Sopranos” “Sons of Anarchy” and “Dexter”. Dexter was a serial killer, but he was “programmed” by his adoptive father to kill only other serial killers. So, he was the hero killing the dragons… …but he was also still a dragon! And, while I don’t want to spoil it for you if you haven’t watched it, I think most people who were into the show knew that it wouldn’t end well for him or those close to him… …and it didn’t!
